Step 1 ‚Äì Set up MakeCode

1- Connect your micro:bit to the computer using the USB cable.

2- Open the MakeCode micro:bit editor.

 

Step 2 ‚Äì Add the Data Logger extension

1- In the block palette, go to Advanced ‚Üí Extensions.


2- In the search bar, type datalogger and click to add it.


3- You‚Äôll see a new menu called Data Logger appear in the block palette (on the left).

Step 3 ‚Äì Create the variables

1- Go to the Variables category in the block palette.

2- Click ‚ÄúMake a Variable‚Ä¶‚Äù.

3- Create three variables with these exact names:

  • light
  • tempC
  • sound

4- You‚Äôll now have blocks available such as set light to‚Ä¶ and show number (light).

 


 

 

Step 4 ‚Äì ‚ÄúOn start‚Äù block

4.1- In Basic, drag the ‚Äúon start‚Äù block to the workspace.

4.2- Inside it, add from Data Logger the block ‚Äúset columns to‚Äù and write exactly:
"light", "tempC", "sound".

Step 5 ‚Äì Add the ‚Äúforever‚Äù block

5.1- In Basic, drag the ‚Äúforever‚Äù block to the workspace.

5.2 ‚Äì Inside the forever block, add:

1- Variables ‚Üí set light to ‚Üí Input ‚Üí light level

2- Variables ‚Üí set tempC to ‚Üí Input ‚Üí temperature (¬∞C)

3- Variables ‚Üí set sound to ‚Üí Input ‚Üí sound level

4- Data Logger ‚Üí log data
‚ÄÉ- create value light ‚Üí value: variable light
‚ÄÉ- create value tempC ‚Üí value: variable tempC
‚ÄÉ- create value sound ‚Üí value: variable sound

5- Basic ‚Üí pause (ms) ‚Üí 5000

Step 6 ‚Äì Download the program

Click ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù in MakeCode.

Step 7 ‚Äì Simulate the eclipse

1- Disconnect the micro:bit from the computer and connect the batteries.

2- Using a torch (flashlight), cover and uncover the light ‚Äî as if the Moon were covering the Sun.

3- Every 5 seconds, the micro:bit will display the light level on its screen and save it in the file MYDATA.

Step 8 ‚Äì Retrieve and analyse

1- Reconnect the micro:bit to the computer.

2- Open the MICROBIT folder and locate the MYDATA file.

3- You‚Äôll see a table with the columns light, tempC, and sound, showing the values recorded every 2 seconds.

4- Create graphs of time vs. light, time vs. temperature, and time vs. sound: you‚Äôll observe how

  • the light values drop when you cover the light (a valley) and rise when the torch shines again,

  • the temperature may change slightly due to the lamp‚Äôs heat, and

  • the sound values can vary with the ambient noise.

üí°Tip:  You can use a spreadsheet (e.g., Excel, Google Sheets, or Calc) for data treatment and to plot the graphs easily

Optional: Switch to Python

Step 1 – Set up MakeCode

1- Connect your micro:bit to the computer using the USB cable.

2- Open the MakeCode micro:bit editor.

 

Step 2 – Add the Data Logger extension

1- In the block palette, go to Advanced → Extensions.


2- In the search bar, type datalogger and click to add it.


3- You’ll see a new menu called Data Logger appear in the block palette (on the left).

Step 3 – Create the variables

1- Go to the Variables category in the block palette.

2- Click “Make a Variable…”.

3- Create three variables with these exact names:

  • light
  • tempC
  • sound

4- You’ll now have blocks available such as set light to… and show number (light).

 


 

 

Step 4 – “On start” block

4.1- In Basic, drag the “on start” block to the workspace.

4.2- Inside it, add from Data Logger the block “set columns to” and write exactly:
"light", "tempC", "sound".

Step 5 – Add the “forever” block

5.1- In Basic, drag the “forever” block to the workspace.

5.2 – Inside the forever block, add:

1- Variables → set light to → Input → light level

2- Variables → set tempC to → Input → temperature (°C)

3- Variables → set sound to → Input → sound level

4- Data Logger → log data
 - create value light → value: variable light
 - create value tempC → value: variable tempC
 - create value sound → value: variable sound

5- Basic → pause (ms) → 5000

Step 6 – Download the program

Click “Download” in MakeCode.

Step 7 – Simulate the eclipse

1- Disconnect the micro:bit from the computer and connect the batteries.

2- Using a torch (flashlight), cover and uncover the light — as if the Moon were covering the Sun.

3- Every 5 seconds, the micro:bit will display the light level on its screen and save it in the file MYDATA.

Step 8 – Retrieve and analyse

1- Reconnect the micro:bit to the computer.

2- Open the MICROBIT folder and locate the MYDATA file.

3- You’ll see a table with the columns light, tempC, and sound, showing the values recorded every 2 seconds.

4- Create graphs of time vs. light, time vs. temperature, and time vs. sound: you’ll observe how

  • the light values drop when you cover the light (a valley) and rise when the torch shines again,

  • the temperature may change slightly due to the lamp’s heat, and

  • the sound values can vary with the ambient noise.

💡Tip:  You can use a spreadsheet (e.g., Excel, Google Sheets, or Calc) for data treatment and to plot the graphs easily

Introduction to Python 

Python is a simple and powerful programming language used all over the world in science, web development, artificial intelligence, and robotics. It‚Äôs great for learning because its commands look almost like normal English, so you can quickly understand what your code does.

With Python, we can make the computer calculate, draw, or collect data, and even explore space-related topics ‚Äî like predicting when and where a solar eclipse will happen. Learning Python helps you think like a scientist and a programmer at the same time.

In MakeCode, click the Python tab (at the top) to view and edit the program in Python.

1- Change the pause time to 1000 ms and test the program.
Observe how recording data every second affects the table and the graphs.

2- Change the temperature to be shown in Kelvin instead of Celsius.

Remember: Kelvin = ¬∞C + 273.15.
